title: Understanding layout
description: Layout is the visual arrangement of elements. It directs attention to the most important information on the screen and makes it easy for users to take action.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Product layouts must adapt to fit different screen sizes and form factors including mobile, tablet, foldable, and large-screen devices. When creating a layout, consider how the spacing and the parts of layout work together.

Material layout guidelines apply to products built for Android and the web.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Column
  2. Fold
  3. Margin
  4. Pane
  5. Spacer
  6. Window
contentChunks.altText: Terms shown on a screen.  Window means the whole screen.  From left to right are columns, a middle fold with a spacer, a pane and a right-side margin.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus

In Progress
FlutterPlanned
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Material layouts and components respond to window size
  • Apps should scale smoothly and meet the needs of multi-device user flows
What’s new

• When creating new layouts, begin from a canonical layout rather than a layout grid. This helps ensure that your layouts can scale across devices and form factors.
  • Window size classes are opinionated breakpoints. Material Design recommends you create layouts for the three window size classes: compact, medium, and expanded.

contentChunks.footer: M3 considers multiple layouts for a variety of sizes
contentChunks.altText: Different layouts for differently sized screens

contentChunks.htmlValue: Layout terms

• Column: one or more vertical blocks of content within a pane
  • Fold: on foldable devices, a flexible area of the screen or, on dual-screen devices, a hinge that separates two displays.
  • Margin: the space between the edge of the screen and any elements inside of it.
  • Pane: a layout container that houses other components and elements within a single app. A pane can be: fixed, flexible, floating, or semi permanent
  • Spacer: the space between two panes
  • Window size class: opinionated breakpoint, the window size at which a layout needs to change to match available space, device conventions, and ergonomics
  • Multi-window mode: enables multiple apps to share the same screen simultaneously
Grouping

Grouping is a method for connecting related elements that share a context, such as an image grouped with a caption. It visually relates elements and establishes boundaries to differentiate unrelated elements.

contentChunks.footer: By placing a caption under an image this composition shows an explicit group.
contentChunks.altText: Photo of dumplings with a caption reading “restaurants in the area”

contentChunks.htmlValue: Explicit grouping uses visual boundaries such as outlines, dividers, and shadows to group related elements in an enclosed area. Explicit grouping can also indicate that an item is interactive, such as list items contained between dividers, or a card displaying an image and its caption.

contentChunks.footer: The elements in this card are explicitly grouped.
contentChunks.altText: Container of a contact grouped with photo and caption

contentChunks.htmlValue: Implicit grouping uses close proximity and open space (rather than lines and shadows) to group related items. For example, a headline closely followed by a subhead and thumbnail image are implicitly grouped together by proximity and separated from other headline-subhead-thumbnail groups by open space.

contentChunks.footer: Images in a carousel are grouped by their proximity.
contentChunks.altText: Carousel of images

contentChunks.htmlValue: Margins

Margins are the spaces between the edge of a window area and the elements within that window area.

Margin widths are defined using fixed or scaling values for each window size class. To better adapt to the window, the margin width can change at different breakpoints. Wider margins are more appropriate for larger screens, as they create more open space around the perimeter of content.

See margin measurements for each window class: compact, medium, and expanded.

contentChunks.footer: A margin separates the edge of the screen from the elements on the screen
contentChunks.altText: Screen highlighting vertical blue margin on left side of screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Spacers
A spacer refers to the space between two panes in a layout. Spacers measure 24dp wide.

contentChunks.footer: A spacer splits two panes from each other.
contentChunks.altText: Screen highlighting vertical blue margin on left side of screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Padding

Padding refers to the space between UI elements. Padding can be measured vertically and horizontally and does not need to span the entire height or width of a layout. Padding is measured in increments of 4dp.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Padding separates a headline from a image above
contentChunks.altText: Full screen-width photo with padding below it and text below the padding

contentChunks.htmlValue: Pixel density

The number of pixels that fit into an inch is referred to as pixel density. High-density screens have more pixels per inch than low-density ones. As a result, UI elements of the same pixel dimensions appear larger on low-density screens, and smaller on high-density screens.

To calculate pixel density:

Screen density = Screen width (or height) in pixels / Screen width (or height) in inches

contentChunks.footer: A high-density UI element
contentChunks.altText: Magnified UI element  showing a high number pixels in the focus area

contentChunks.footer: A low-density UI element
contentChunks.altText: Magnified UI element  showing the low number of pixels in the focus area

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density-independent pixels

Density-independent pixels, written as dp (pronounced "dips"), are flexible units that scale to have uniform dimensions on any screen. They provide a flexible way to accommodate a design across devices. Material UIs use density-independent pixels to display elements consistently on screens with different densities.

A dp is equal to one physical pixel on a screen with a density of 160.

To calculate dp: dp = (width in pixels * 160) / screen density

contentChunks.footer: Low-density screen displayed with density independence
contentChunks.altText: Screen with grid representing  low number of pixels

contentChunks.footer: High-density screen displayed with density independence
contentChunks.altText: Screen with grid representing  high number of pixels

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Screen physical widthScreen densityScreen width in pixelsScreen width in dp
1.5 in120180px240dp
1.5 in160240px240dp
1.5 in240360px240dp
Information density

A layout’s spacing dimensions (including margins, spacers, and padding) can change to increase or decrease its information density. High density layouts can be useful when users need to scan, view, or compare a lot of information, such as in a data table. Increasing the layout density of lists, tables, and long forms makes more content available on-screen.

contentChunks.footer: Consider using higher density information design when users need to scan lots of information on screen
contentChunks.altText: High density layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: However, dense layouts can be less accessible because interactive elements are smaller, so use caution when increasing information density.

contentChunks.footer: Avoid reducing selectable targets to less than 48x48dp
contentChunks.altText: Selectable target of only 40 dp

contentChunks.footer: Don’t increase density in UIs that involve focused tasks, such as interacting with a dropdown menu or picker as it reduces usability by limiting selectable space.
contentChunks.altText: Dropdown menu selectable space  height of 36 dp

contentChunks.footer: Don't increase the density in components that alert the user of changes, such as snackbars or dialogs.
contentChunks.altText: Single-line snackbar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density scale

The density scale allows you to control the internal spacing of individual components when needed.

The density scale is numbered, starting at 0 for a component’s default density. The scale moves to negative numbers (-1, -2, -3) as space decreases, creating higher density. Each increment represents a decrease in the height of a component by 4dp.

contentChunks.footer: Buttons are offered in multiple densities to best fit a needs of a design
contentChunks.altText: Three buttons, with densities  of +1, ), and -1

contentChunks.htmlValue: When multiple elements are stacked vertically within a component, use 4dp increments to separate them. Center the grouped element within the component container.

contentChunks.footer: The measurement between the label and input is 20dp
contentChunks.altText: Stacked element showing 20 dp between label and input

contentChunks.footer: The label and input are centered within their parent container
contentChunks.altText: Parent container showing label above input

contentChunks.htmlValue: Don’t apply density to interaction targets. They should remain a minimum of 48x48dp, even if their visual element (such as an icon) is smaller.

contentChunks.footer: The interaction target for an icon button can be larger than its icon, as long as it meets the 48x48dp minimum size.
contentChunks.altText: Settings button is 24 by 24 dp, but has interaction target of 48 x 48 dp.

contentChunks.footer: The interaction target of a common button can be larger than its icon, as long as it meets the 48x48dp minimum size.
contentChunks.altText: Button with height of 36 dp and interaction target of 48 dp

contentChunks.footer:
Most layouts have two regions:

  1. Navigation
  2. Body

contentChunks.htmlValue: Navigation region

The navigation region holds primary navigation components and elements such as:

  • Navigation drawer
  • Navigation rail
  • Navigation bar

Elements in this section help people navigate between destinations in an app or to access important actions.

contentChunks.footer: Three different navigation components suit a variety of device sizes and environments.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Body region

The body region contains most of the content in an app, including:

  • Images
  • Text
  • Lists
  • Cards
  • Buttons
  • App bar
  • Search bar

Content in the body region is grouped into one or more panes.

contentChunks.footer: 1. The body region is the area outside of the navigation region.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Panes

A pane refers to the grouping of content within the body region. All app content is inside one or more panes.

The arrangement and relative size of the layout regions and panes will vary depending on the device’s window size class:

  • Compact: 1 pane
  • Medium: 1 (recommended) or 2 panes
  • Expanded: 1 or 2 panes (recommended)

contentChunks.footer:
1. First pane
  2. Second pane

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Pane types

  • Fixed: fixed width (360 dp)
  • Flexible: responsive to available space, can grow and shrink

contentChunks.footer:
1. First pane
  2. Second pane

contentChunks.htmlValue:
A pane is different from a window, which refers to the frame containing an app. Multi-window views are a system UI feature used to display more than one app simultaneously.

Multi-window support guide for Android

contentChunks.footer: Two windows shown next to one another with a taskbar underneath.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Layouts

Single-pane layouts use one flexible pane.

contentChunks.footer: A singular pane extending from one edge to another inside a window.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Two-pane layouts typically use one fixed and one flexible pane, which can appear in whatever order is best for the content.

contentChunks.footer:
1. First pane
  2. Second pane

contentChunks.htmlValue: An alternative two-pane layout, called split-pane, uses two flexible panes equal to 50% of the screen width. This layout best supports foldable devices.

contentChunks.footer:
1. First pane
  2. Second pane

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Number of panesPane type
1Flexible
21 fixed, 1 flexible
2 (split-pane)2 flexible

App bars

Panes can include a top app bar and bottom app bar.

contentChunks.footer: An example of an app bar inside a pane.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Any nesting actions within the top app bar should be hidden or revealed based on available width.

contentChunks.footer: A compact window with two actions revealed.
A expanded window class with five items revealed.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When layouts transition from one to two panes, avoid shifting elements between panes.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t move elements to different UI objects when switching between window classes.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Columns

Content in a pane can be displayed in multiple columns to segment and align content. 

Columns are exclusive to a pane and are not used at the window level.

contentChunks.footer: Using one pane, an app like News uses multiple columns of content to create its layout

contentChunks.htmlValue: Window size classes provide the foundation for top level layout decisions, but display-specific considerations are also needed.
Display cutout

A display cutout is an area on some devices that extends into the display surface. It allows for an edge-to-edge experience while providing space for important sensors on the screen of the device. 

Applications can extend around display cutouts or other features, but some parts of the UI might be obscured.

contentChunks.footer: A mobile device’s content safe area around a display cutout for the front-facing camera.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Foldable devices
Foldable devices use a folding mechanism to fold and unfold. They have unique characteristics to consider when designing layouts.

Fold

The fold of a foldable device divides the screen into two portions, either horizontally or vertically. The fold can be a flexible area of the screen or, on dual-screen devices, a hinge that separates two displays.

A flexible fold is barely visible, although some users may feel a tactile difference on the screen surface. Content can flow over the fold fairly easily.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Folds are typically found in the center of the device screen and can present a seamless experience.

contentChunks.htmlValue: On devices with a physical hinge, designing the screen as two distinct sections (separate window areas or panes) allows a composition to work well across the hinge and screens.

contentChunks.footer: A physical hinge separates two parts. There is no display hardware in this region.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Device state

Foldable devices can have several physical states: folded, open flat, and tabletop.

Folded

The folded state can include a front screen, which often fits in the compact window size class, just like a mobile phone in portrait orientation.

contentChunks.footer: The front screen of a foldable device

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Open flat

An open flat state refers to the fully opened screen, which usually increases the window size class to medium or expanded. An open device can be used in landscape or portrait orientations.

contentChunks.footer: In an open portrait state, the longer device edge is vertical while the shorter edge is horizontal.
In an open landscape state, the longer device edge is horizontal while the vertical edge is shorter.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tabletop

Tabletop refers to a half-opened state forming a rough 90 degree angle, with one half of the device resting on a surface. This posture resembles a laptop.

UI controls near the fold can be difficult for users to access, and text overlaying the fold can be hard to read.

contentChunks.footer: If camera hardware is present, a tabletop device is best positioned on a side without any protruding hardware elements.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Interaction

App continuity

When running on a foldable device, an app can transition from one screen to another automatically. After the transition, the app should resume in the same state and location, and the current task should continue seamlessly.

Large screen compatibility tests

contentChunks.footer: A news app shows a feed in a compact and expanded window class when a foldable device switches device state.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling and multiple panes

Depending on how your app uses panes, the scroll behavior of a folded design may change in the unfolded design. 

If you expand a pane, you can decide whether the whole window will scroll together or if each side (each pane) scrolls independently.

contentChunks.footer: A single pane can scroll its inside content vertically and horizontally.

contentChunks.htmlValue: If your design has multiple panes, each pane can operate as an independently scrollable area.

contentChunks.footer: Multiple panes can scroll inside content independently of one another.
